text.title: Make a 'Virtual PC' on Your USB Device
text.head: Make a 'Virtual PC' on Your USB Device
text.p: You can take everything you need with you on your USB device (such as a flash drive, external hard drive, iPod, etc). Keep reading for detailed instructions on how to make a virtual PC on your thumb drive.
text.head: Steps
Installing an Operating System

list.item:
Configure your USB device. To make a virtual PC on your USB device, you'll need the following things:
8GB USB storage device
Windows 7 DVD or ISO image file
Microsoft WAIK software
NT6 FAST Installer
Download the Windows Automated Installation KIT (WAIK) for Windows 7. Click here for the download.
Install the Windows Automated Installation Kit. Open the StartCD.exe file.
Click on the Windows AIK Setup option. It's on the left side of the window.
Click Next.
Agree to the License Terms. Click "I Agree" and select Next.
Select the installation folder. You can leave it as the default (C:\Program Files\Windows AIK\) or select a new location. Click Next.
Confirm the installation. Click Next.
Complete the installation. When you see that the installation has been completed, click Close.

figure.rend: Make a 'Virtual PC' on Your USB Device Step 10.jpg

list.item: Click Download in the upper-left corner.
Select NT6_Fast_Installed.zip from the download list.
Extract the zip file. Right click on it and select Extract to NT6_Fast_Installer\.
Right-click on the INSTALLER.cmd file and select Run as Administrator. A command window will open up.
Press Enter to continue.
Press any key to chose the install.wim file.
Select the install.wim file from the Windows 7 DVD. You can find it in the sources folder.
Choose the operating system image number. For Windows 7 Pro, choose number 4.
Choose a target USB drive letter to install the operating system. For this example, we'll choose K.
Choose the target boot drive. Again, in the example, we'll use K.
Choose to install the operating system on the USB drive. Enter y for yes.
Chose a Windows drive letter for new instillation. For the example, we'll use L.
Press Enter to start installation.
Boot the operating system. Once your installation has reached 100%, you can boot the operating system from your USB drive.

text.head: Installing Applications

list.item: Determine what applications you will need to take with you or access when away from your normal computing location. At the very least, install an email client (if your email provider allows POP3 access) and an Internet browser. You may also want office-type applications as well as some entertainment sources.
Download applications that have been designed or re-engineered for portable use. You can search the Internet using key words, or head to some sites devoted to portable computing.
Install (extract) your chosen applications to your USB device and take it with you.

Browse this list of suggested applications. You might find some of these useful on a USB drive:

7-zip portable — Archive manager
AceMoney Lite — Financial tracking software

FreeOTFE — Free disk encryption software
GIMP Portable — Image Manipulator
Google Talk — Portable version

Pidgin Portable — Multi-network IM (formerly known as Gaim)
Portable Scribus — Portable Publishing Tool

TrueCrypt — Free disk encryption software
uTorrent — Lightweight BitTorrent client

text.head: Tips

list.item: Not everything is fully portable. Check for changes that need to be made on some applications.

Run backups often! Changes are made to files each time you use the application. This is especially true with email and browser apps. USB devices are small compared with PC drives, so backing up your entire USB device to your PC should be no problem.
